awd_titl_txt: Submesoscale sea ice-ocean interactions in marginal ice zones
awd_abstract_narration:
Identifying critical processes governing marginal ice zone (MIZ) dynamics remains one of the key challenges in our ability to comprehend and accurately model the rapidly changing polar oceans. MIZs are regions of strong mixed layer gradients in ocean temperatures and salinities, indicating that enhanced ocean variability at relatively small spatial scales ought to be present there. However, quantitative estimates of the role of small scale flows in MIZ dynamics are currently missing, and climate models do not parameterize these non-linear processes. This research will test the hypothesis that energetic vertical velocities at relatively small scales can efficiently bring the oceanic heat in contact with the sea ice and affect its melt rates. The research is of critical importance to society for understanding how sea ice and ocean circulation evolve under modified surface forcing conditions in a changing climate. The research activity will develop a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce by establishing interdisciplinary collaborations among several U.S. academic institutions and broadening participation of underrepresented groups. The project will primarily fund a post-doctoral scientist who will be trained with broad exposure to the fields of physical oceanography and remote sensing. The investigators will contribute to enhancing society's scientific and technological understanding by engaging in undergraduate and graduate teaching activities, mentoring summer undergraduate students and participating in high-school outreach activities.

The project will use a submesoscale-permitting global ocean model together with a set of idealized numerical experiments to diagnose the characteristics of submesoscale flows in various MIZs, classify their generation mechanisms, and assess their cumulative impact on sea ice melt rates. Critical forcing will be identified by conducting hydrodynamic stability analysis and by evaluating MIZ processes driving the potential vorticity towards negative values characteristic of sub-mesoscale flows. An energy budget analysis will be explored to understand submesoscale sources and sinks, and reveal the role of sea ice-ocean drag in damping upper-ocean variability. A theoretical framework explaining sea ice velocity and concentration patterns will be developed and used together with satellite data to observationally constrain submesoscale vertical velocities in the ocean. The project implements a synergetic triad of high resolution numerical simulations, theory development, and observational data analysis, representing a timely and unique opportunity to transform our understanding of sea ice-ocean interactions in MIZs. The research will result in a global estimate of submesoscale sea ice-ocean heat fluxes and, supported by satellite observations of sea ice patterns in MIZs, provide a theoretical framework to identify oceanic and atmospheric conditions under which submesoscale heat fluxes prevail. The remote sensing component will unify observations from multiple satellites and create a novel set of two-dimensional observations of ocean vorticity at submesoscales that could be used to directly test and advance upper-ocean turbulence theories. Upon completion, this research project will advance our knowledge of submesoscale sea ice ocean interactions and reveal missing ocean-ice heat pathways; results will also improve future predictions of sea ice extent.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A prominent signature of global warming is the dramatic decrease in Arctic summer sea ice extent and thickness over recent decades.  These changes have led to an increase in a region known as the marginal ice zone, or MIZ.  The MIZ refers to the area where sea ice transitions from being fully concentrated and tightly packed to the open ocean where sea ice has completely melted.  Changes to the MIZ have led to weaker and more mobile sea ice as well as increased regions where the ocean is exposed to the atmosphere, known as leads.  The Southern Ocean MIZ, or seasonal ice zone, has also changed dramatically in the past few years, for reasons that are less clear than in the Arctic.  Our project has focused on the physical processes that link the movement of upper ocean currents to sea ice and how this coupling influences the transfer and distribution of heat and momentum in polar regions.  These physics are critical to the future evolution of sea ice in both hemispheres, and in turn, impacts global aspects of our climate including atmospheric temperatures and precipitation patterns.  

Satellite remote sensing has provided quantitative estimates of sea ice areal changes in recent decades, but there remain several important limitations.  Estimation of sea ice thickness from satellites continues to be a challenging measurement, making sea ice volume estimates much more uncertain.  Additionally, remote sensing only provides information about surface ocean properties, and in large parts of the Arctic and Southern oceans, the warmest waters reside a few hundred meters below the surface.  Thus, the climate community continues to rely heavily on numerical simulations to both understand and predict the evolution of the coupled atmosphere-ice-ocean system.  The traditional means of representing sea ice dynamics in climate models is to treat the ice as a continuous material that can behave as either a viscous fluid or a rigid body under various conditions.  In reality, sea ice in the MIZ is comprised of individual sea ice floes, distinct pieces of ice that range in size between several meters to tens of kilometers.  These sea ice floes have a comparable scale to coherent ocean circulation feature that are both generated by the sea ice, such as the formation of density gradient due to ice melt, and affected by the sea ice through ocean-ice drag.  These interactions between upper ocean turbulent flow and sea ice floes are not accurately captured in typical climate models that are used to predict changes on decadal to centennial time scales.  Thus, these interactions represent a blind spot related to potential feedbacks and tipping points in the climate system.

Our study has illustrated a number of important ocean-sea ice coupled processes that occur at roughly 1-km spatial scales that impact sea ice melt.  At these scales, ocean vertical velocities become enhanced, which can efficiently deliver heat from the ocean interior to the surface.  In work completed through this project, we have demonstrated that ocean-ice heat fluxes are dominated by local contributions from coherent but intermittent ocean eddies as well as small-scale filaments and internal waves that episodically carry heat to the base of sea ice.  Additionally, we have shown that the behavior of these small-scale currents and their associated heat transport are strongly effected by frictional processes, or dissipation, that occurs at the interface between the ocean and the ice.  This leads to a modulation between regions of heavily concentrated ice, where energetic ocean eddies are preferentially dissipated, and the low-concentrated MIZ where vertical heat transport is enhanced.  Our work suggests that continued Arctic sea ice loss will give rise to a positive feedback in which reduced sea ice will produce more energetic eddies and amplified ocean-ice heat exchange.  We also highlight the need for sea-ice aware representations of these coupled physics in climate models.  A major effort of this project was to develop these representations, or what are referred to as parameterizations.  These advances include modifications to open ocean parameterizations that determine the depth of the ocean?s mixed layer to include the effects of sea ice drag.  Additionally, we developed an idealized sea-ice model that was coupled to a regional ocean model to develop and validate a series of simple relationships, or scaling laws, that relate sea-ice melt rates to sea ice floe size, wind speed and the magnitude of ice-ocean friction.  This project identified paths for implementing these new scaling laws and parameterizations in global climate models.

This project supported multiple undergraduate and graduate students as well as two postdoctoral scholars and provided training on a rapidly growing research area in the climate sciences.  This work led to the development of new modeling capabilities and initiated new collaborations with larger modeling research groups.  The work also supported PI Manucharyan as he established a new research group at the University of Washington.
